Some people may miss Cherry Tree High Comedy Club(the older game) gameplay, where you could do some random tasks,talk with poeple and walk around town, but the story is still great. If you liked the predecessor, you should buy this game. Its cheap,its kawaii,its fun,i dont know...it feels and looks nice, even with some weird bugs sometimes. Its like watching an anime. A slice of life anime. Its great!

reviewText: A direct sequel to Cherry Tree High Comedy Club. This time it's a kinetic visual novel. The plot this time around is that the club is now formed and a pop idol has decided to transfer into Cherry Tree to follow her lifelong dream of comedy. It's more or less a slice of life anime in visual novel form. It's cute & well written overall. I was able to read through it in just under 2 hours. If you're a slow reader then this will probably take around 3. It definitely does not overstay its welcome. I also love how the game is split up into Main Episodes" & "Sub Episodes". If you just want to read the main plot and avoid any sort of side story or filler you can easily. Sub Episodes pop up after every chapter or two and you can read them if you wish. They don't effect the main plot in any way and are just cute little scenes to break up the main plot. I loved how they handled it.\n\nIf I were to have any complaints it's that there is no way to view previously read text
date: save mid chapter or set the game at any resolution besides 640x480 (Windowed or Fullscreen). The steam overlay also doesn't seem to work either. It's nothing serious and it barely hurts the game at all! Would reccomend to all fans of the first game!"

reviewText: Although it doesn't continue the time management gameplay of the last game (to my sadness, somewhat) this one is a short, sweet, and linear (there are no branching paths or such) visual novel. It's a great visual novel however, and if you liked the characters of the first game at all you'd be in crazy town to miss this. It's more cute and silly slice-of-life stuff, with some touching themes about friendships.

reviewText: A direct sequel to Cherry Tree High Comedy Club, in the form of a kinetic novel. As such, there is no interaction or gameplay. You simply choose a chapter like a book and read the story. However, it does use the same engine and sprites as the previous game, meaning the characters will move around in the same way they do during scripted events in the previous game.\nPick this up if you enjoyed CTHCC more for the story and characters rather than the gameplay/simulation aspect.

reviewText: Did you enjoy the first game but think it could have done with less of something resembling gameplay and more idols? Then is this the game for you! It takes place right after the ending of the first game, introduces a few new characters, and basically ends right when things are getting interesting. Mairu or Mary or Marino or whatever the hell her name is finally has the club up and running, but still has to deal with finding her one true comedy partner. Meanwhile, Ai Fujino, an ordinary girl by day and Japan's most famous pop idol by night, moves to town with the goal of joining aforementioned comedy club. Anime ensues.\n\nMy final verdict is that if you liked the first game (or at least liked the characters) and want to see more, you'll most likely enjoy this. Not sure if the usual asking price is worth it (the game is short, I was done long before the final card dropped), but having gotten it on sale I can say I have no regrets. I give this an awkward thumbs up. Like, pretend my hand is waving a little so my thumb dips sideways occasionally and I'm saying eehhhhh" while I do it."

reviewText: Cherry Tree High I! My! Girls! continues the story of <insert name of whatever version you happened to play the first time around, then replace it with the original Japanese installment. Having the original Westernized version launch on steam for the prior game with the optionto use both, then scaling back to this version is the first strike. Secondly, the game isn't a game, its a visual novel, you watch episodic content and press enter, no choices, no exploration and no gameplay, unlike its predecessor which offered all of the aforementioned. The game is also extremely short with the content lasting only a couple hours and ends inconclusively unlike the first game. The only redeeming quality is that it does continue the story of the characters, and they stick to their formula, albeit the writting this time around is cliche. Unfortunately despite the previous installment being quite an enjoyable experience, this game cannot be recommended unless one is seeking a subpar visual novel.

reviewText: Cherry Tree High I! My! Girls!, is a visual novel which follows Cherry Tree High Comedy Club. It includes some new characters, music, as well as locations . The story revolves around a new transfer student who is an international singer, but secretly wants to join the Cherry Tree High Comedy Club. As a visual novel, it is cute, anime-like, and has some amusing dialogue. I think it is a decent visual novel sequel to a fun game. I recommend playing Cherry Tree High Comedy Club first, so you have the backstory and are not lost. Visually it looks like an anime, though I would have liked to see a little more movement to go with the story. Thumbs Up

reviewText:
Short but sweet.

If you are expecting something substantial you will be disappointed. The game can easily be finished in just a few hours.

Neither would I call this really a sequel to CTHCC. It is at best a short addendum or spinoff of the first game. There isn't much in the way of story, it is more a nice way to revisit the characters you know and love and spend a little more time with them.

The game is definitely not recommended for those who have not played CTHCC, you will get little to nothing out of playing this. If you have played though and loved the characters, this is a short and fun little addition to that story.

reviewText:
This game will tell us a story. It is a story about what happened after the Cherry Tree High Comedy Club (CTHCC) got founded (in the previous installment).
I liked the storyline, and I also liked how some new characters have been introduced. You'll get to know a little bit more about all the members of CTHCC.

Please note that this is a visual novel - a story. You can watch the main chapters one by one, and you can watch them again later if you want. Also, side chapters (sub chapters) will be unlocked at several points in the main storyline. But - and this is a difference with the first installment - you do not make any choices in this game. It is just a story.

What I also like is that they have tried to stay true to the original Japanese context: even though all the text is in English, they did not do an overhaul to typical American things. It still has the authentic Japanese feeling.

Especially for the relatively low price, it is not a bad game (read: story) to buy, even though it normally takes you only 2 or 3 hours to complete it (watch all the chapters).

What they could do better, though, is add an easier way to quit the game: the only way I could find to stop it, is by pressing Alt-F4. With Alt-Enter you can toggle between fullscreen and windowed mode. I preferred the fullscreen mode, but that is just a personal preference.

Finally, while watching the chapters, I was hoping that I would see the CTHCC actually perform an act on stage for a live audience. The game stops before this point. I can certainly understand why they did that, though. This way a third game can be added to the storyline, and perhaps you can make choices in that game that will determine how well they will do on their performance. But we'll have to wait for that.

I recommend this game, but I also want to say that you should have played the first game (Cherry Tree High Comedy Club) at least once successfully (or seen a Let's Play of it somewhere) in order to fully understand some of the scenes in this sequel.
voteText: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
It follows up on the previous story perfectly and handles the same humor the main game did. To this end they repurpose the games previous graphical engine to a simple graphical novel. And in that novel Mairu fights yet another scheme of her eternal rival and has to successfully lead her new club to find her one true partner.
That being said, this novel delivers on its promise to spin the tale further, but regretably ends on a cliffhanger and right in the middle of the whole story. Even the idea of Ai Mai Girls is left hanging in the air. This is not well done, especially with the title being Ai Mai Girls! The story feels dropped off, not as if a chapter is closed at least. If there is no part 3 to this storyline it will leave a sour taste for every reader. But even if there is a third installment, the long wait might hurt the story overall, as there was no closure to build on, having the chance to feel like a delayed DLC in the end.

I propose getting this if you liked the game and enjoy reading in general. But if you want closure for your heroes, you might want to either end on the main game or wait for part 3. Thus, this review is entirely neutral. By lack of a neutral option, I go for buy it if you really liked the story of the game and only then.

reviewText:
There is no westernized version of this game, so if you played that version of the first game, you'll likely spend the first half of this sequel trying to re-learn all the character's names. This game also has no gameplay, but with how the gameplay worked in the first game, that's actually an improvement in my opinion, others may vary.

With there being no gameplay, there are really just a few things to review, the music and scenery is pretty much all just reused from the first game, so there's not much to talk about there. The story is a continuation of the first game, and without giving story spoilers all I can say is that the story just didn't seem to go anywhere. There was no climax or anything in the story, and the ending just seemed to come out of nowhere, it didn't feel like an ending whatsoever.

If you played and enjoyed everything about the (non-westernized version of) previous game in the series except the gameplay, I'd recommend picking this up when it goes on sale, otherwise, you should probably just pass on this entirely.

reviewText:
All in all, an alright visual novel.

It's okay. While you get to make decisions in Cherry Tree High Comedy Club, I! My! Girls! is just a standard visual novel. It takes place straight after the first game and consists of 7 main story episodes of the comedy club members, well, being in the comedy club, and 5 sub episodes which focus on characters other than Mairu and Ai.

The problem with I! My! Girls! is that not much really happens and the ending doesn't actually feel like an ending. The main story has 7 episodes, but they don't feel too connected. Still, it's around 3 hours of entertainment and doesn't cost much. If you enjoyed the first game, you might as well give I! My! Girls! a shot.

reviewText:
Sometimes you do not know to give thumbs up or down. Why you ask.
Because you expect, being part 2, to follow up on the same rules.
It doesn't do that. First part was a game with a good story, now it is only a story. No choices, no skills to level up, no places to go to.
Does it make it a bad thing.
NOOOO, because it is a very good story, funny as well (I find it funny, doesn't mean you would). They have character. How i wished it had audio as well. So you could have it as an audiobook. It's short, so you don't need to save. Although people complain about it, it isn't nice to do. If an episode only takes 15 minutes, what is the problem that you dont have a save. Dont start it if you only have a few minutes.
I enjoyed it very much, except the ending. Somehow they must make a third part, because otherwise your story isn't complete.

reviewText:
If you were expecting like what happened in the first game, stop. If you haven't played Cherry High comedy club, play that first before buying this.

This is just a kinetic novel, not gameplay in itself. It shares stories about what happens after Mairu starts the comedy club, but really it doesn't complete anything.

I didn't mind reading it and watching it, but it did leave me unsatisfied for the completion of the Comedy Club. I really wished the game would have went on.

It was still well made though and may satisfy other people than I so I only reccommend it at low price and if you really want a contiuation of the first game that bad.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Removes all of the gameplay elements of the first game in favor of pure text scroll.

Most of the characters from the first game are sidelined in favor of a new, less interesting new one, with only a few bonus chapters that focus on them.

It's at least an hour or two shorter than the first and lacks any replayability.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: Even shorter than CTHCC, CTHIMG removes the gameplay elements featured in the prior game for a full on visual novel style with a few graphics. I was a tad disappointed, but the characters and their interactions made it all worth it. All the characters were out in full force, and since you dont have to recruit everyone theres much more CHARACTER behind them.\nWhere the previous game made me feel as though I had missed a game in the beginning, this game opens right up from where the last one left off, and it continues its writing very well. In all honestly, the gameplay elements from the last game actually took away from the writing, and it shines through more than ever in this installment.\nUnfortunately, the same looping music returns, and the whole VN plays out like a sequel hook (which it is), so you wont be very satisfied with the ending as it is. At the low price that it is, I fully recommend it, and give it a very solid 7/10.

reviewText:
I'll be honest, its boring. Theres so much reading involved eventually you give up on reading and start skipping ahead without realizing it. I like the art and music, so that makes up for it, I guess. Plot's pretty good, but the way they execute it is in such a way that its just, boring. I don't have any other words to describe it. The comedy is pretty stale and cliche too.

Story - 3/5
Art - 4/5
Music - 3.5/5
Execution - 1.2/5

Should you play?
Ehh... No. Unless you're willing to sit through a long lecture of stale jokes, sure, go for it.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
As a sequel to Cherry Tree High Comedy Club, I had expectations.  Expectations of a short entertaining interactive story.  I got more than I bargained for on short however.  Clocking in at just over an hour for the main story for a fast reader, this novel manages to be even more condensed than the original.  The extra chapters however, are nice and add another 40 minutes of content.  The actual story is good, but feels much narrower.  If I was to compare to the original with its interaction of seven characters and supporting cast, I! My! Girls! has a cast of four and support.  While not an issue in itself, it still pushes me towards the not recommended conclusion.  Storywise it is very similar to the original.  It stills has the charm and humor, but seems to be lacking in direction.  No goal to overcome here.  The biggest surprise for me though is the complete lack of interaction.  This title is now a kinetic visual novel.  No choice beyond which chapter to read and no gameplay whatsoever.  I would stick to the original unless you just absolutely love the story and characters and need more of them.

Pros:
+Art design - Just as good as the original; still love the look of this series.
+Bonus chapters - I enjoyed them more than the main story.

Meh:
~Characters - While I still like the characters, I feel they whiffed a bit on execution.
~Music - More of the same.  Nothing wrong, nothing noteworthy.
~Translation - Not sure what happened here, they seem to have skimmed over some localization of Japanese terminology here and there.  Might be oversight, might be me missing something.  Nothing breaks down and I am not docking the game for it, just odd...

Cons:
-Short - And I mean short.  For me 65 mins for the main story and 35 mins for the bonus chapters.  Compounded by...
-Gameplay - Or the lack thereof.  Now I am not opposed to visual novels, however I did not expect it to lack all interaction when coming from the original.  There is no value in playing/reading CTHIMG more than once.  A real shame considering I did enjoy the time management and exploration in CTHCC.
-Graphics - Same gripe as prior game, no resolution options and fullscreen stretches.

TL;DR - A somehow shorter followup kinetic novel to CTHCC that is only for major fans of the characters/story.

Note: My playtime beyond 1hr 40min is trading card idle time.

reviewText: Slow paced, boring, and weird.  I'm definitely not a visual novel guy that has this much fluff about nothing.

reviewText: This visual novel was great!\n\nI was just craving to read a visual novel of some kind so I picked this game up and the story was satisfying. Not to say that you should expect a totally new story that would blow people's minds, but if you just want to read something without the demand for a totally original plot, I'd say it's not a bad purchase. (I started reading the sequel first though before Comedy Club" because the sequel had a lower rating
date: so I bought the complete pack just so I can slowly warm up to all the plots. Besides
recommended: who is unfamiliar with stories being told in non-chronological orders?)\n\nEvery soundtrack in the game was surprisingly catchy. Weirdly better than a lot of soundtrack music from other visual novel games I listened to
hoursPlayed: even better than soundtracks that most animes use (Depends on what other people do watch). I even wish the developers were selling the complete soundtrack album so I could buy it and play the songs while in a way
voteText: showing support for the producers.\n\nThe artstyle is pretty. It's a nice tough that I can look at characters move around
helpfulPercent: while there are zoomed-in versions of them with clear emotions.\n\nOne downfall with this game is the fact that I can't backlog the dialogues so everytime I space-bar to the next line without paying attention
votesHelpful: I feel like I may be missing something critical to the story. But it's been made up by the fact that the episodes are divided up so you can selected which chapters to read from if something feels incomplete. And to the end of the story
votesTotal: it didn't seem like I missed anything anyways.\n\nAnother downfall is that the game is locked to 640x480

commentsCount: but that didn't bother me too much.\n\nOverall

reviewText:
I don't understand why there are some words written in English and some in Italian....it's so confusing @.@
Actually if you want to read a nice story you should buy this game. If you want some audio, some choises and a longer story full of details and explanations you should not buy this.

If you press F1 you can set some things, other than that there is nothing that you can change or setup.
If you reduce the game in your programs bar, you'll not deselect it, so you can't just chat without playing the game ( which will go furter without you noticing it).
Personally I think there is still some work to do with this title, so I'll not recomend it until it will have some fixes.

reviewText:
As a sequel to Cherry Tree High Comedy Club, I had expectations.  Expectations of a short entertaining interactive story.  I got more than I bargained for on short however.  Clocking in at just over an hour for the main story for a fast reader, this novel manages to be even more condensed than the original.  The extra chapters however, are nice and add another 40 minutes of content.  The actual story is good, but feels much narrower.  If I was to compare to the original with its interaction of seven characters and supporting cast, I! My! Girls! has a cast of four and support.  While not an issue in itself, it still pushes me towards the not recommended conclusion.  Storywise it is very similar to the original.  It stills has the charm and humor, but seems to be lacking in direction.  No goal to overcome here.  The biggest surprise for me though is the complete lack of interaction.  This title is now a kinetic visual novel.  No choice beyond which chapter to read and no gameplay whatsoever.  I would stick to the original unless you just absolutely love the story and characters and need more of them.

Pros:
+Art design - Just as good as the original; still love the look of this series.
+Bonus chapters - I enjoyed them more than the main story.

Meh:
~Characters - While I still like the characters, I feel they whiffed a bit on execution.
~Music - More of the same.  Nothing wrong, nothing noteworthy.
~Translation - Not sure what happened here, they seem to have skimmed over some localization of Japanese terminology here and there.  Might be oversight, might be me missing something.  Nothing breaks down and I am not docking the game for it, just odd...

Cons:
-Short - And I mean short.  For me 65 mins for the main story and 35 mins for the bonus chapters.  Compounded by...
-Gameplay - Or the lack thereof.  Now I am not opposed to visual novels, however I did not expect it to lack all interaction when coming from the original.  There is no value in playing/reading CTHIMG more than once.  A real shame considering I did enjoy the time management and exploration in CTHCC.
-Graphics - Same gripe as prior game, no resolution options and fullscreen stretches.

TL;DR - A somehow shorter followup kinetic novel to CTHCC that is only for major fans of the characters/story.
